App¶

app.py is the main app document for the web app. It contains all of the routes and handles all requests between the server and client.

author:Andrew Bruce
year:2018
app.account(user_id)[source]¶

Account route

This route requires authentication

Takes in a user id and returns that users account page.

Parameters:user_id – current users id (primary key)
Returns:html template for account page
app.add_address()[source]¶

This route returns a template to allow a user to add a new address

app.addresses(user_id)[source]¶

This route returns the addresses for the user that requests it.

This route takes the user ID as a parameter as it needs it for the url

app.after_request(response)[source]¶

Handles all actions after server request.

This is a built in Flask function that fires after each server request. I use it to close the database connection, then it returns the response from the browser.

Parameters:response – browser response
Returns:any response from the browser
app.before_request()[source]¶

Handles all actions before request.

This is a built in Flask function that fires before each server request. I use this to do a number of things -

  1. Establishes a connection to the database.
  2. Assigns the current user to a global variable
  3. Finds the current users open order and assigns to a global variable
  4. Find the current users basket amount and assigns to a global variable
  5. Checks the status of all orders under the current user for tracking.
app.create_product()[source]¶

Route that returns the page for administrators to create products.

On this route it takes input from the create product form and uses a method inside the Product class to create a product in the database.

app.create_user()[source]¶

Create user route.

Route can only be accessed if user role is “admin”

Takes in POST data from html form and calls create_user(). Unlike the register() route it takes in a user role and assigns it to the created user.

Returns:html template with create user form
app.delete_address(address_id, user_id)[source]¶

This route removes an address

An address id is passed in from the link, it then calls methods in the model to remove the address

app.edit_address(address_id, user_id)[source]¶

This route returns a template to allow a user to edit an address

app.index()[source]¶

Route that returns the index(home) page

app.load_user(userid)[source]¶

Loads the user between sessions.

Takes in the user id stored in the cookies and uses it to pull the user from the database.

Parameters:userid – users primary key id
Returns:the user object
app.login()[source]¶

Login route.

Handles POST data from the login form then validates credentials against hashed credentials in database. If login is correct then it calls Flasks login_user() method which creates an authentication cookie. If not it gives an error.

Returns:A html template containing the login form
app.logout()[source]¶

Logout route.

This route requires authentication

Calls Flasks logout_user() method which removes authentication cookies. Then redirects user to the login page. :return: a redirect for the login page

app.not_found(error)[source]¶

Route that returns a custom 404 page if the user encounters that error

app.orders(user_id)[source]¶

Orders route

This route requires authentication

Pulls the current users placed, dispatched, complete, and canelled orders and assigns them to variables. It then returns a html template and passes the lists of orders in.

Parameters:user_id – current users id (primary key)
Returns:html template displaying passed in user orders
app.register()[source]¶

Registration route.

Takes POST data from html form and calls create_user() which creates a user in the database, with the default user role of “customer”. It then calls Flasks login_user() method and redirects the user home.

Returns:html template containing registration form
app.send_email(subject, reply_to, recipient, body, html)[source]¶

Function for sending emails.

Takes the parameters mentioned below and uses them to send an email using the outgoing SMTP settings I have declared in the app.

Parameters:
  • subject – email subject
  • reply_to – reply address
  • recipient – email recipient
  • body – email body
  • html – html file to style body
Returns:

sends an email with the html file
app.set_address_default(address_id)[source]¶

This route is used to change the default address

It is fired when the Set Default link is clicked on the address. It takes the new address Id in as a parameter
